sources.title: Near the Rainbow's End (1930) BOB STEELE
sources.description:
Stars: Bob Steele, Lafe McKee, Al Ferguson
Director: J.P. McGowan

In Bob Steele's very first talking picture, a simmering dispute between cattle ranchers and sheep herders over grazing rights threatens to boil over into a full-fledged range war.

metadata.Plot: Despite past friendliness, cattle ranchers Tom and Jim Bledsoe, father and son, fence off their range to prevent its use by neighboring sheep ranchers Tug Wilson and Buck Rankin, suggesting that they hope to end their recent loss of cattle. Rankin (not Rankins) shoots Tug, who is unaware of Rankin's lawless activities, in an argument and Jim is accused of murder and also stampeding the sheep. Believing Jim is guilty, Tug's daughter, Ruth, aids Buck in capturing Jim, but he escapes. Ruth gets help from Sheriff Hank Bosley, and a sheepherder, Sanchez, reveals Rankin's responsibility for both the rustling of Bledsoe's cattle and the killing of Wilson.
metadata.Actors: Bob Steele, Lafe McKee, Al Ferguson
